page.title: 15LOCAL HISTORY_PLACE NAMES
page.content: There are numerous names in this area originating from Roman or Saxon times. Flyford Flavell is a corruption of ffrith-forest; 'ford' meant a way through it (not necessarily water). Flavell was probably a Roman family name (Flavious) which was 'Normanised' to Flavell. Piddle comes from 'pedal' - footstones through a brook. Streams used to be wider and shallower (silting); stepping stones were quite common and were even used by horses. North Piddle was a brook name probably to the north of Naunton. Naunton Beauchamp (possibly saxon) -'Newton' a settlement with family ownership dating from 156O, Beauchamp - french for beautiful fields. Abberton is the place name found in the original Domesday Book, probably Saxon Eadbuld's (Tun).
